utils package

Submodules

utils.analysis_utils module

Utilities for running static analysis tools like Ruff and Bandit.

utils.analysis_utils.run_ruff_analysis(target_path: Path) → Tuple[bool, List[Dict[str, Any]]][source]

Runs Ruff on a file/directory and returns PASS/FAIL and issues.

utils.analysis_utils.run_bandit_analysis(target_path: Path) → Tuple[bool, List[Dict[str, Any]]][source]

Runs Bandit on a file/directory and returns PASS/FAIL and issues.

utils.analysis_utils.generate_analysis_report(ruff_success: bool, ruff_issues: List[Dict[str, Any]], bandit_success: bool, bandit_issues: List[Dict[str, Any]]) → Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

Combines issues into a standard report format.

utils.chroma_utils module

Utilities for interacting with ChromaDB for context storage.

utils.chroma_utils.get_chroma_client() → ClientAPI | None[source]

Provides a singleton ChromaDB client instance based on configuration.

Reads configuration using utils.config_loader.

Returns:

An initialized ChromaDB client (HttpClient or PersistentClient) or None if config fails.

async utils.chroma_utils.get_or_create_collection(collection_name: str) → Collection | None[source]

Helper to get or create a collection, returning the collection object or None.

async utils.chroma_utils.add_documents(collection_name: str, documents: List[str], metadatas: List[Dict[str, Any]] | None = None, ids: List[str] | None = None) → bool[source]

Adds multiple documents to a specified Chroma collection.

async utils.chroma_utils.get_documents(collection_name: str, doc_ids: List[str], include: List[str] | None = ['metadatas', 'documents']) → Dict[str, Any] | None[source]

Retrieves documents from a collection by their IDs.

async utils.chroma_utils.query_documents(collection_name: str, query_texts: List[str] | None = None, query_embeddings: List[List[float]] | None = None, n_results: int = 5, where_filter: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, where_document_filter: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, include: List[str] | None = ['metadatas', 'documents', 'distances']) → List[Dict[str, Any]] | None[source]

Queries a Chroma collection by text or embeddings.

async utils.chroma_utils.get_document_by_id(collection_name: str, doc_id: str, include: List[str] | None = ['metadatas', 'documents']) → Dict[str, Any] | None[source]

Retrieves a single document by its ID.

Adds or updates a single document (basic upsert).

utils.goal module

Utilities for parsing and validating the goal.txt file.

utils.goal.parse_goal_file(file_path: str) → Tuple[str | None, str | None][source]

Parses the goal.txt file to extract goal and environment descriptions.

Expects the file to contain lines starting with ‘goal:’ and ‘env:’.

Parameters:

file_path – The path to the goal.txt file.

Returns:

A tuple containing (goal_description, environment_description). Returns (None, None) if the file cannot be read or doesn’t contain the expected keys.

utils.goal.validate_goal_content(goal: str | None, env: str | None) → Dict[str, bool][source]

Performs basic validation checks on the parsed goal and environment.

Parameters:

  • goal – The parsed goal description string.

  • env – The parsed environment description string.

Returns:

True, ‘env_present’: False}).

Return type:

A dictionary indicating validation results (e.g., {‘goal_present’

utils.logger_setup.setup_logging()[source]

Configures root logger based on settings from config.yaml or defaults.

Reads logging configuration (level, format, file, max_bytes, backup_count) from the loaded configuration.

# Args: # <<< Remove Args if parameters are removed, or update if kept >>> # max_bytes: Maximum size of the log file before rotation. # backup_count: Number of backup log files to keep.

utils.prompt_manager module

Manages loading of core and stage-specific prompt files.

exception utils.prompt_manager.PromptLoadError[source]

Bases: Exception

Custom exception for errors during prompt loading, parsing, or rendering.

utils.prompt_manager.format_as_bullets(items: List[str]) → str[source]

Formats a list of strings as a bulleted list.

utils.prompt_manager.to_json_filter(value) → str[source]

Converts a Python object to a JSON string (simple version).

class utils.prompt_manager.PromptManager(server_stages_dir: str, common_template_path: str)[source]

Bases: object

Loads, caches, and renders prompts from individual YAML files using Jinja2.

get_stage_definition(stage_number: int | float | str) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Retrieves the definition for a specific stage number.

get_rendered_prompt(stage_number: int | float | str, context_data: Dict[str, Any] | None = None) → str[source]

Loads the specific stage YAML, merges data, and renders the full prompt using Jinja2.

Parameters:

  • stage_number – The number of the stage to render the prompt for.

  • context_data – Additional context data to inject into the template (e.g., reflections_summary).

Returns:

The fully rendered prompt string for the specified stage.

Raises:

PromptLoadError – If stage definition, YAML files, or templates have issues.

utils.state_manager module

Manages the project status file (project_status.json) with file locking.

exception utils.state_manager.StatusFileError[source]

Bases: Exception

Custom exception for errors related to status file operations.

class utils.state_manager.DummyFileLock[source]

Bases: object

A dummy lock object that does nothing, for testing or when locking is disabled.

acquire(timeout=None)[source]
release()[source]
class utils.state_manager.StateManager(target_directory: str, server_stages_dir: str, use_locking: bool = True)[source]

Bases: object

Handles reading, updating, and validating the project status file.

Uses file locking to prevent race conditions during updates.

get_last_status() → Dict[str, Any] | None[source]

Gets the status entry for the highest stage in the latest run.

Finds the run with the highest run_id and returns the last status update within that run’s status_updates list.

Returns:

The last status dictionary from the latest run, or None if no runs or statuses exist.

get_full_status() → Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Any]]][source]

Gets the entire status structure (including all runs).

Returns:

[…] }.

Return type:

The full status dictionary { ‘runs’

Raises:

StatusFileError – If the status file cannot be read or parsed.

get_next_stage() → int | float | None[source]

Determines the next stage to be executed based on the latest run.

Logic: - Reads the status file and finds the latest run. - Finds the highest stage number marked as DONE or PASS in that run. - Lists available stage definition files (stage*.yaml) in server_stages_dir. - Returns the lowest available stage number greater than the highest completed stage. - Returns 0 if no runs or no completed stages exist in the latest run.

Returns:

The next stage number (int or float), or None if an error occurs.

update_status(stage: int | float, status: str, artifacts: List[str], reason: str | None = None) → bool[source]

Updates the status file by adding a new entry to the latest run.

Creates the first run (run_id: 0) if no runs exist. Validates input status. Adds a timestamp to the new entry. Writes the updated list back to the file.

Parameters:

  • stage – The stage number (e.g., 1.0, 2).

  • status – The result status (e.g., “PASS”, “FAIL”, “DONE”).

  • artifacts – A list of relative paths to generated artifacts.

  • reason – Optional reason, e.g., for FAIL status.

Returns:

True if the update was successful, False otherwise.

store_artifact_context_in_chroma(stage_number: float, rel_path: str, content: str, artifact_type: str = 'unknown') → bool[source]

Stores a single artifact’s content and metadata in ChromaDB synchronously.

get_artifact_context_from_chroma(query: str, n_results: int = 5, where_filter: Dict[str, Any] | None = None) → List[Dict[str, Any]][source]

Retrieves artifact context from ChromaDB based on a semantic query (synchronous).

persist_reflections_to_chroma(run_id: int, stage_number: float, reflections: str) → bool[source]

Persists reflections for a given stage to ChromaDB synchronously.

get_reflection_context_from_chroma(query: str, n_results: int = 3, filter_stage_min: float | None = None) → List[Dict[str, Any]][source]

Retrieves relevant reflections from ChromaDB based on a semantic query (synchronous).

list_artifact_metadata(stage_filter: float | None = None, artifact_type_filter: str | None = None, limit: int | None = None) → List[Dict[str, Any]][source]

Retrieves artifact metadata based on filters, without semantic search.

utils.template_helpers module

Helper functions for manipulating template strings or structures.

utils.template_helpers.inject_variable(template: str, variable_name: str, value: str) → str[source]

Injects a simple string variable into a template.

Replaces placeholders like {{variable_name}}.

Parameters:

  • template – The template string.

  • variable_name – The name of the variable (without brackets).

  • value – The string value to inject.

Returns:

The template with the variable injected.

utils.template_helpers.inject_multiple_variables(template: str, variables: Dict[str, str]) → str[source]

Injects multiple string variables into a template.

Parameters:

  • template – The template string.

  • variables – A dictionary where keys are variable names and values are strings.

Returns:

The template with all variables injected.

utils.template_helpers.format_list_section(template: str, section_name: str, items: List[str], item_format: str = '- {item}') → str[source]

Formats a list of items into a specific section of a template.

Replaces a placeholder like ### SECTION_NAME ###

…content… ### END_SECTION_NAME ###

or simply {{section_name}} with a formatted list.

Args:

template: The main template string. section_name: The name of the section (used in placeholders). items: A list of strings to format. item_format: A format string for each item, where {item} is the placeholder

for the list item itself (default: “- {item}”).

Returns:

The template with the list formatted into the specified section.

utils.tool_adapters module

Adapter functions for executing external tools and MCP commands.

exception utils.tool_adapters.ToolExecutionError(message: str, stdout: str | None = None, stderr: str | None = None)[source]

Bases: Exception

Custom exception for errors encountered during tool execution.

utils.tool_adapters.execute_tool(tool_name: str, tool_def: Dict[str, Any], arguments: Dict[str, Any]) → str[source]

Executes a defined tool (CLI command) with provided arguments.

Parameters:

  • tool_name – The name of the tool being executed.

  • tool_def – The tool definition dictionary (containing ‘command_template’, etc.).

  • arguments – A dictionary of arguments provided for the tool execution.

Returns:

The standard output of the executed command as a string.

Raises:

ToolExecutionError – If the tool definition is invalid, arguments are missing, the command fails, times out, or produces errors.

async utils.tool_adapters.call_mcp_tool(mcp_client: Any, tool_name: str, arguments: Dict[str, Any]) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Placeholder for calling another MCP tool via a client instance.

Parameters:

  • mcp_client – An initialized MCP client object (e.g., from fastmcp).

  • tool_name – The name of the MCP tool to call.

  • arguments – The arguments for the MCP tool.

Returns:

The result dictionary from the MCP tool call.

Raises:

ToolExecutionError – If the MCP call fails.
